Two studies led by researchers at the University of California, San Diego have revealed that cigarette smoke not only harms human health but also fuels the growth of antibiotic-resistant bacteria, specifically MRSA (Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus), and strengthens the virulence of these bacteria. The studies, published in the journal Infection and Immunity and Infection and Immunity Reports, respectively, show that cigarette smoke enhances the ability of MRSA to invade human cells and resist antibiotics.

Passage 1 focuses on the first study, which was led by Dr. Laura Crotty Alexander and her team. They discovered that cigarette smoke exposure increases the production of a protein called MRSA-associated collagen-binding protein (MSCBP) in human lung cells. This protein helps MRSA attach to and invade the cells more effectively. Additionally, cigarette smoke exposure weakens the immune response of the lung cells, making it harder for the body to fight off MRSA infections.

Passage 2 discusses the second study, which was led by Dr. Shu-Fang Wang and her team. They found that cigarette smoke enhances the expression of virulence genes in MRSA, making the bacteria more resistant to antibiotics and more harmful to human cells. The researchers also noted that the smoke-exposed MRSA bacteria were more likely to form biofilms, which are protective layers that shield bacteria from antibiotics and the immune system.

Both studies emphasize the importance of avoiding cigarette smoke to reduce the risk of MRSA infections and complications. The researchers hope that their findings will lead to new strategies for preventing and treating MRSA infections, particularly in populations that are heavily exposed to cigarette smoke, such as healthcare workers and patients in hospitals.

In related news, a study published in the journal Infection and Immunity found that MRSA infections are more common and severe in smokers than in non-smokers. The study, led by Dr. Jianhua Zhang of the University of California, Davis, showed that smokers had higher levels of MRSA in their lungs and were more likely to develop pneumonia and other complications when infected with the bacteria. The researchers suggest that smoking may weaken the immune system and make it easier for MRSA to colonize the lungs.
answers: Superbugs such as MRSA are already bad enough. But it turns out that something can make them even nastier: cigarette smoke. Researchers found that antibiotic-resistant bacteria exposed to the smoke became more aggressive and far more difficult to kill, they explain at Eureka Alert. It's almost as if the smoke sets off an alarm that causes the bacteria to strengthen its defenses, explains the Union-Tribune of San Diego. Scientists made the discovery by exposing immune cells to two different batches of MRSA, one normal and one treated with cigarette smoke extract. The bigger the dose of smoke, the bigger the effect, notes Medical Daily. "We already know that smoking cigarettes harms human respiratory and immune cells, and now we've shown that, on the flipside, smoke can also stress out invasive bacteria and make them more aggressive," says lead author Laura Crotty Alexander of UC San Diego. It's a double-whammy: Smokers already have weakened immune systems that make them more susceptible to infectious diseases, and the smoke they inhale seems to make invading pathogens even more dangerous. In this study, the smoke helped MRSA survive longer and kill more mice with pneumonia. (The latest antibiotic-resistant bug to make headlines is a nasty stomach virus.)

Which colors they led to can be found by their shapes, and the melanosomes in Caihong were long and flat like pancakes—similar to those found in hummingbirds, which boast iridescent plumage. Although they can't pick out from the Pantone wheel Caihong's exact colors, researchers say the creature likely sported feathers with a "rainbow glimmer." Three new studies published in the journal Science have challenged the notion of a "human revolution" in behavior and toolmaking that occurred around 300,000 years ago. Instead, researchers now believe that technologically advanced behaviors and toolmaking emerged much earlier, around 700,000 years ago, in Africa.

The studies, which were based on excavations in Kenya and Tanzania, reveal that our ancestors were making complex stone tools and exhibiting advanced behaviors much earlier than previously thought. These discoveries include the use of obsidian for toolmaking, which requires long-distance trade, and the creation of stone tools with multiple functions.

The findings also suggest that climate change may have played a role in driving the development of advanced behaviors and toolmaking. The researchers found evidence of a wetter climate around 700,000 years ago, which may have led to the expansion of hominid populations and the need for more advanced tools to adapt to new environments.

The studies also challenge the idea of a "revolutionary" leap in human behavior and toolmaking around 300,000 years ago. Instead, the researchers suggest that the development of advanced behaviors and toolmaking was a gradual process that began much earlier.

The findings have important implications for our understanding of human evolution and the origins of modern behavior. They also challenge the notion that Africa was a "cradle of civilization" only in the last few hundred thousand years.

The studies also highlight the importance of ongoing research and excavations in Africa, which continue to reveal new insights into the complex history of human evolution.

In summary, new discoveries in Africa suggest that advanced behaviors and toolmaking emerged much earlier than previously thought, around 700,000 years ago, and that climate change may have played a role in driving this development. The findings challenge the notion of a sudden "human revolution" and instead suggest a gradual evolution of human behavior and technology.
answers: For decades, the human story was one told through signs of modernity—art, tools, burials—found only after Homo sapiens left Africa. Recent discoveries pushing back the date of departure are helping to change that narrative, as are three new studies in Science. Together, they describe the earliest stone tools of their kind in East Africa as well as the earliest evidence for long-distance transport of raw materials in the region, per Science News. Researchers previously believed the Early Stone Age marked by large, primitive tools (hand axes and cleavers) made way for the Middle Stone Age and its smaller tools (spearpoints and blades) around 280,000 years ago. But stone tools found in Kenya's Olorgesailie Basin show hominin groups—it's not clear which species is responsible—had developed these more advanced tools approximately 320,000 years ago. "We see a smaller technology, a more diverse series of stone tools … designed for specific purposes," researcher Rick Potts tells NPR. An expert not involved in the study says the tools are so "prepared and retouched" they suggest the Middle Stone Age likely started even earlier. What drove it? Microscopic and chemical analyses of the region's soil show the landscape was rapidly shifting between wet and dry conditions, meaning hominins might have been forced to adapt. But as the technology also coincides with the emergence of Homo sapiens in Africa, it's possible that the human mind deserves credit. The tools themselves suggest the development of trading networks, too. Some were made of rocks carried from 55 miles away, says Potts. Others were made of obsidian from as far as 30 miles away, per the Conversation. (These stone tools are also making waves.)

answers: Forget satellite images and aerial searches—the best way to find Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 may be with mathematical techniques dating back to the 18th century, the BBC reports. That's how Air France flight 447 was found in 2009, using "Bayesian statistics" to measure the probability of the plane being in one place or another. Named after Presbyterian minister and mathematician Thomas Bayes, the technique allowed experts to apply several factors to each point on a map: For example, what was the chance it crashed from mechanical failure? How far do planes tend to crash from their last known location? What was the chance that search teams missed debris in various locations? It's like picking a restaurant by balancing how full it is, what your favorite restaurant-review website says, and so on—except that experts hunting for Airbus A330 did that for each point where plane may have crashed in the Atlantic, Five Thirty-Eight notes. It was so hard that the US team of statisticians invited by France gave up, until they de-emphasized one statistic: that a plane's black box emits a signal after a crash 90% of the time. They changed their findings, and presto, the plane was found. Bayesian techniques have helped people find World War II U-boats, men overboard, and sunken treasure, but there's no evidence that Malaysia is employing them now. "I suspect that they just guess, like professional baseball managers used to do before Moneyball," says a biostatistician.
